ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This directed research taught me about what it means to do a psychology study in a hands-on way, by learning to recruit participants and run the study.
I learned about the basics of research and how you develop an idea into a study by doing literature reviews and collecting pilot data. I also learned how labs are structured.
Independent research skills, drafting literature review, extensive grant-writing skills, establishing community partnerships.
General social psychology knowledge as well as the ability to conduct independent research
Learned more about emotional granularity and other projects in lab

I learned how to deeply engage with a research project idea by conducting an extensive literature review; how to design an experiment and distill it such that it clearly answers your main question without being too convoluted; how to present a research topic and idea in a lab meeting; how to implement the project on Qualtrics; and the basics of data analysis on R.

I learned a lot about how certain psych-neuroscience research within the early adversity realm is being conducted, including information about statistical analysis, experimental design, manuscript writing, etc.
I learned to new computational techniques, had to write a research report, and also gave a presentation in front of the lab
I worked in the Mind and Development Lab, and became familiar with running developmental psychology studies with child participants.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was a very helpful way of getting to know how to do research, and the lab meeting conversations, readings, etc. helped supplement that experience.
I like being able to be an RA for credit and can't think of a way the system can be improved in general
Loved the format and was very flexible for my dynamic schedule.
The direct engagement with a renowned professor truly contributed to my learning
Very interesting to work in this research lab

Strengths: Working one-on-one with a research mentor is an unparalleled way of deeply engaging with ideas and acquiring many skills, in a safe and supportive environment. Attending lab meetings also provides access to the broader lab community, fascinating discussions, and an accurate glimpse into academia beyond undergrad, which can be very clarifying if you're considering that route. 
Weaknesses: Any weaknesses I can identify only were due to the COVID remote semester.

Strengths: a lot of autonomy
Weaknesses: not a lot of accountability (depending on lab structure, etc.)

Strengths - very supportive mentors, flexible work schedule, learned a lot
Weaknesses - no prominent weaknesses, perhaps a bit more structure would be good
very unstructured

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The research translated well to Zoom/virtual/remote contexts!
Doesn't really apply here; the zooms were fine and similar to other classes I had.
The lab meetings and individual meetings were able to be carried out over Zoom quite successfully each week

My mentors were incredibly accommodating when I had to cancel meetings due to mental or physical health challenges this semester; they were both academically and personally supportive throughout this very hard time.

Given that this was an independent research course, my expectations were not very high of doing COVID research. I felt pretty isolated and without much accountability for doing my work until the time of thesis deadlines, but I am not sure how that could be improved, given that I couldn't come into the physical lab space to work, and most of my work was not directly supervised by design anyway.

Succeeded - weekly lab meetings were still very helpful, writing a report and giving a presentation was not hindered at all by COVID-19
Improved - again, perhaps a bit more structured guidance throughout the semester would be good.
more meetings/real time interaction wouldve been appreciated

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend doing directed research if you're interested in getting to apply what you're learning in the psych major to a meaningful experience and contribute to an important cause!
Yes I would say to get lab experience
Yes, great for completing 4 semester credit without the stress of 4 complete classes. It is a good mix to your schedule.
Definitely! This direct research was more fulfilling than many of my courses
yes if interested in emotional affect

Absolutely. Learning theory and technical skills in classes pales in comparison to exploring your own ideas and seeing your project start to come to fruition in a research setting. Mentorship in the Crockett lab is especially unparalleled.
Yes I would! Especially for completion of graduation requirements within the psychology or cognitive science majors, particularly if interested in doing thesis project with this credit.
I would recommend this course to another student. I learned a lot of new computational techniques, learned how to engage with older mentors, and also communicate my findings and research
Yes, if you want to get research experience!
easy way to get a psych credit

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A virtual lab for psych research credit
Weekly checkins and participation in lab meetings
Independent research.
This was independent research conducted at the Yale School of Medicine in the Garrison lab.
Weekly virtual lab meetings and individual meetings
N/A
Virtual research and lab meetings
I mostly did independent lab work, with semi-regular check-in meetings with by graduate student mentor, as well as attending lab meetings.
Independent work.
n/a
We ran studies over Zoom, had lab meetings over Zoom, and did independent work and research.
independent lab work
